clusters.title: Putin, Xi and Modi speak briefly before SCO summit
clusters.neutral_headline: Putin, Xi, and Modi Meet at SCO Summit in China

items.title: Putin, Xi and Modi speak briefly before SCO summit
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin spoke with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit's opening session. Acc...
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin spoke with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit's opening session. Acc...

items.title: China and India discuss disputed border at key summit - as Putin talks about Trump
items.standfirst: At a time when Donald Trump's foreign policy continues to frustrate some and perplex others, Vladimir Putin, Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi have gathered to discuss trade and international security.
items.content: At a time when Donald Trump's foreign policy continues to frustrate some and perplex others, Vladimir Putin, Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi have gathered to discuss trade and international security.

items.title: Sco Summit: Xi aims at showing global south unity, with Modi and Putin
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". Shirli Sitbon has more.
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". Shirli Sitbon has more.

items.title: SCO Summit: Putin, Modi join Xi in Tianjin amid Trump tariff war
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.

items.title: Putin, Modi and other world leaders in China for summit
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are among the 20 world leaders attending a regional security summit in China.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are among the 20 world leaders attending a regional security summit in China.

items.title: China and India pledge to be 'partners not rivals'
items.standfirst: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi met on the sidelines of a summit that Russia's Vladimir Putin is also attending.
items.content: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi met on the sidelines of a summit that Russia's Vladimir Putin is also attending.

items.title: India and China seek a business reboot
items.standfirst: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi travels to China this weekend for his first visit in seven years, joining Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin at a regional security summit in Tianjin. The trip comes amid strained relations with Washington, just days after the US doubled tariffs on Indian exports to 50% in response to New Delhi’s continued purchases of Russian oil. FRANCE 24 welcomes the editor-in-chief of the China-Global South Project, Eric Olander, to discuss the rapprochement between India and China.
items.content: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi travels to China this weekend for his first visit in seven years, joining Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin at a regional security summit in Tianjin. The trip comes amid strained relations with Washington, just days after the US doubled tariffs on Indian exports to 50% in response to New Delhi’s continued purchases of Russian oil. FRANCE 24 welcomes the editor-in-chief of the China-Global South Project, Eric Olander, to discuss the rapprochement between India and China.

ai_summary: Putin, Xi Jinping, and Narendra Modi spoke briefly before the SCO summit's opening session.
The summit in Tianjin, China, aims to boost Beijing's influence and promote a multipolar world order.
China and India discussed their disputed border on the sidelines of the summit.
The summit is attended by leaders from around 20 countries, including Russia and India.
Modi's visit to China is his first in seven years, joining Xi Jinping.

items.content: In the dead of night, the Trump administration tried to deport more than 600 Guatemalan children back to their home country.

items.title: Guatemala says it suggested that U.S. send its unaccompanied migrant children home

items.content: As a U.S. federal judge blocked the deportation of unaccompanied Guatemalan children, the government of Guatemala says in a statement it suggested the U.S. return its children to their home country.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Why it matters: Some of the children were on planes facing deportation within hours when District Judge Sparkle…

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration move to deport Guatemalan children
items.standfirst: Advocacy groups sought emergency action amid reports planes carrying the children were about to take off.
items.content: Advocacy groups sought emergency action amid reports planes carrying the children were about to take off.

items.title: Judge orders US to halt deportation of hundreds of Guatemalan children
items.standfirst: Washington judge says unaccompanied children cannot be deported for at least 14 days as legal process unfoldsA US judge on Sunday ordered an emergency halt to a plan by the Trump administration to deport a group of nearly 700 unaccompanied Guatemalan children back to their home country after immigrant advocates lawyers called the plan “illegal”.Attorneys for 10 Guatemalan minors, ages 10 to 17, said in court papers filed late on Saturday that there were reports that planes were set to take off within hours for the Central American country. But a federal judge in Washington said those children couldn’t be deported for at least 14 days, and after a hastily scheduled hearing on Sunday, she enforced that they needed to be taken off the planes and back to the Office of Refugee Resettlement facilities while the legal process plays out. Continue reading...
items.content: Washington judge says unaccompanied children cannot be deported for at least 14 days as legal process unfoldsA US judge on Sunday ordered an emergency halt to a plan by the Trump administration to deport a group of nearly 700 unaccompanied Guatemalan children back to their home country after immigrant advocates lawyers called the plan “illegal”.Attorneys for 10 Guatemalan minors, ages 10 to 17, said in court papers filed late on Saturday that there were reports that planes were set to take off within hours for the Central American country. But a federal judge in Washington said those children couldn’t be deported for at least 14 days, and after a hastily scheduled hearing on Sunday, she enforced that they needed to be taken off the planes and back to the Office of Refugee Resettlement facilities while the legal process plays out. Continue reading...

items.title: US judge blocks government from deporting unaccompanied Guatemalan minors
items.standfirst: District Judge Sparkle Sooknanan's emergency order follows a legal complaint brought on behalf of 10 children.
items.content: District Judge Sparkle Sooknanan's emergency order follows a legal complaint brought on behalf of 10 children.

ai_summary: A judge blocked the Trump administration's deportation of over 600 Guatemalan children.
The Guatemalan government suggested the U.S. return unaccompanied migrant children.
A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order against the deportations.
The judge's order halts the deportation of hundreds of unaccompanied minors.
Advocacy groups sought emergency action due to imminent deportations.

items.title: Zelenskiy Says Suspect Apprehended in Killing of Andriy Parubiy
Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and Maidan protest leader assassinated in Ukraine
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, a leading figure in Ukraine’s 2014 pro-European "Maidan" protest movement, who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy, 54, also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council. Caroline Baum reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, a leading figure in Ukraine’s 2014 pro-European "Maidan" protest movement, who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy, 54, also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council. Caroline Baum reports.

items.title: Investigation launched into ‘horrific murder’ of Ukrainian politician in Lviv
items.standfirst: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...
items.content: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...

items.content: President Zelensky said the killing of Parubiy was a "terrible murder" - with a manhunt under way.

clusters.title: Houthis detain at least 11 UN workers in raids on two agencies in Sana’a
clusters.neutral_headline: Houthis detain at least 11 UN workers in raids on two agencies in Sana’a

items.title: Houthis detain at least 11 UN workers in raids on two agencies in Sana’a
items.standfirst: UN condemns ‘arbitrary detentions’ by Iran-backed group at World Food Programme and Unicef offices in YemenThe Iranian-backed Houthis raided offices of the UN’s food, health and children’s agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining at least 11 employees, as the rebels tightened security across Sana’a after the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several cabinet members.The UN envoy for Yemen, Hans Grundberg, said on Sunday evening: “I strongly condemn the new wave of arbitrary detentions of UN personnel today in Sana’a and Hodeidah … as well as the forced entry into UN premises and seizure of UN property. At least 11 UN personnel were detained.” Continue reading...
items.content: UN condemns ‘arbitrary detentions’ by Iran-backed group at World Food Programme and Unicef offices in YemenThe Iranian-backed Houthis raided offices of the UN’s food, health and children’s agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining at least 11 employees, as the rebels tightened security across Sana’a after the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several cabinet members.The UN envoy for Yemen, Hans Grundberg, said on Sunday evening: “I strongly condemn the new wave of arbitrary detentions of UN personnel today in Sana’a and Hodeidah … as well as the forced entry into UN premises and seizure of UN property. At least 11 UN personnel were detained.” Continue reading...

items.title: Houthi rebels detain at least 11 UN personnel, envoy to Yemen says
items.standfirst: The United Nations envoy to Yemen, Hans Grundberg, condemned the “arbitrary detentions” of at least 11 UN staff by Houthi rebels on Sunday and demanded that they be “immediately and unconditionally” released. Those arrested included seven World Food Programme employees and three UNICEF workers, a security source in Sanaa told AFP.
items.content: The United Nations envoy to Yemen, Hans Grundberg, condemned the “arbitrary detentions” of at least 11 UN staff by Houthi rebels on Sunday and demanded that they be “immediately and unconditionally” released. Those arrested included seven World Food Programme employees and three UNICEF workers, a security source in Sanaa told AFP.

items.content: Yemen's Houthi rebels have raided United Nations offices and detained several people, officials have said.

items.standfirst: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations' food and children's agencies in Yemen's capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said.
items.content: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations' food and children's agencies in Yemen's capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said.(Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman/AP)

ai_summary: Houthi rebels raided UN offices in Yemen, detaining at least 11 personnel.

Seven WFP employees and three UNICEF workers were among those detained.
The detentions occurred in Sana'a, Yemen's capital.

clusters.title: 8/31: Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's Immigration Crackdown in Chicago Faces Backlash

items.title: 8/31: Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan
items.standfirst: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem discusses the federal government's deployment to U.S. cities, while Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker discusses the administration's plans for Chicago. Plus, World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain discusses the situation in Gaza.
items.content: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem discusses the federal government's deployment to U.S. cities, while Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker discusses the administration's plans for Chicago. Plus, World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain discusses the situation in Gaza.

items.title: Noem confirms more ICE resources are heading to Chicago for immigration crackdown
items.standfirst: Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem on Sunday said that the Trump administration will soon expand immigration operations in Chicago, confirming plans for a stepped up presence of federal agents in the nation's third-largest city as President Donald Trump continues to lash out at…
items.content: Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem on Sunday said that the Trump administration will soon expand immigration operations in Chicago, confirming plans for a stepped up presence of federal agents in the nation's third-largest city as President Donald Trump continues to lash out at…

items.title: JB Pritzker calls for ‘all to stand up’ to Trump’s immigration crackdown in Chicago
items.standfirst: President is preparing for controversial federal takeover of US city in crusade against immigration ‘sanctuary cities’Illinois’s governor JB Pritzker has called on “all to stand up” to Donald Trump as the US president prepares to launch a federally led immigration crackdown across Chicago, a plan which has been met with widespread backlash from local leaders and the public.Pritzker’s comments come as White House officials vow to target Chicago next in its sweeping immigration crackdowns across the country. Recently, the White House requested that a US military base on the outskirts of Chicago assist with immigration operations as the Trump administration plans a broader takeover of Democratic-run “sanctuary cities”. Continue reading...
items.content: President is preparing for controversial federal takeover of US city in crusade against immigration ‘sanctuary cities’Illinois’s governor JB Pritzker has called on “all to stand up” to Donald Trump as the US president prepares to launch a federally led immigration crackdown across Chicago, a plan which has been met with widespread backlash from local leaders and the public.Pritzker’s comments come as White House officials vow to target Chicago next in its sweeping immigration crackdowns across the country. Recently, the White House requested that a US military base on the outskirts of Chicago assist with immigration operations as the Trump administration plans a broader takeover of Democratic-run “sanctuary cities”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Homeland Security Secretary confirmed more ICE resources for Chicago.
Illinois Governor Pritzker called for opposition to Trump's crackdown.
The White House plans a federally led immigration crackdown in Chicago.
The administration is targeting "sanctuary cities" with immigration operations.
A military base near Chicago may assist with immigration operations.

items.content: The Global Sumud Flotilla will try to break the Israeli blockade of the Palestinian territory and bring humanitarian aid, food, water and medicine to Gaza as Israel steps up its offensive in Gaza City.

items.content: Greta Thunberg has set sail for Gaza as part of the largest flotilla of boats carrying aid for the Strip.

items.title: Israeli airstrikes and gunfire have killed 30 around Gaza City, local officials say
items.standfirst: Toll includes 13 people trying to get food near distribution point, as Israeli cabinet to discuss next stages of offensive Israeli airstrikes and gunfire killed at least 30 people in and around Gaza City, local health authorities said, as a 20-boat humanitarian aid flotilla carrying activists including Greta Thunberg set sail from Barcelona for the stricken territory.Authorities said the toll from Israeli tank and gunfire included 13 people who died trying to get food near a distribution site in the Gaza Strip, two in a house in Gaza City and 15, including five children, in a strike on a residential building on Saturday.With Reuters and Agence France-Presse Continue reading...
items.content: Toll includes 13 people trying to get food near distribution point, as Israeli cabinet to discuss next stages of offensive Israeli airstrikes and gunfire killed at least 30 people in and around Gaza City, local health authorities said, as a 20-boat humanitarian aid flotilla carrying activists including Greta Thunberg set sail from Barcelona for the stricken territory.Authorities said the toll from Israeli tank and gunfire included 13 people who died trying to get food near a distribution site in the Gaza Strip, two in a house in Gaza City and 15, including five children, in a strike on a residential building on Saturday.With Reuters and Agence France-Presse Continue reading...

The flotilla set sail from Barcelona for the stricken territory.

items.title: Indonesia protests: president scraps lawmakers’ perks in bid to calm tensions
items.standfirst: Police set up checkpoints across Jakarta on Monday after deadly protests that have forced Prabowo Subianto to remove perks include a housing allowance worth 10 times the minimum wageIndonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto has pledged to revoke lawmakers’ perks and privileges, including a controversial $3,000 housing allowance, in a bid to ease public fury after nationwide protests in which six people have died.Flanked by leaders of eight Indonesian political parties, Prabowo told a televised news conference in the capital, Jakarta, that they had agreed to cut the housing allowance and suspend overseas trips for members of parliament. It was a rare concession in response to mounting public anger. Continue reading...

items.title: First the great migration, now the big hold: why workers are staying put

According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in…
items.content: The tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold. According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in…

items.title: First the great migration, now the big hold: why workers are staying put
items.standfirst: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job marketThe tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold.According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in their current roles through 2025. They gave reasons like having “positive company culture” and “feeling professionally fulfilled” or “being well compensated” at their current job. But there’s also a fourth reason why so many are staying put: the job market isn’t great and people are worried. Continue reading...
items.content: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job marketThe tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold.According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in their current roles through 2025. They gave reasons like having “positive company culture” and “feeling professionally fulfilled” or “being well compensated” at their current job. But there’s also a fourth reason why so many are staying put: the job market isn’t great and people are worried. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A Robert Half survey indicates 73% of workers plan to stay in current roles.
Workers cite positive company culture and professional fulfillment as reasons.
Many feel well compensated in their current jobs, according to the survey.
The job market's weakness also contributes to workers staying put.
The "great migration" of job-hopping is officially over, the survey suggests.
